com.percussion.cms.objectstore
Class PSComponentProcessorProxy

java.lang.Object
  com.percussion.cms.objectstore.PSProcessorProxy
      com.percussion.cms.objectstore.PSComponentProcessorProxy
All Implemented Interfaces:
IPSComponentProcessor
public class PSComponentProcessorProxy
extends PSProcessorProxy
implements IPSComponentProcessor

This class presents the interfaces supported by the processor classes, but doesn't actually perform any work. It has a configuration file that is read to find the appropriate processor given a component type. That processor is instantiated and is used to perform the heavy lifting. Once the processor type is known, the config is searched for associated properties for the supplied component and procesor. These properties are made available to the real processor. The default processors support web services and direct server access both locally and remotely.

See the config schema, sys_CmsProcessorConfig.xsd for details on the format of the configuration file.

To provide an idea of how it will work, let's look at what happens when an operation is performed on a remote client using web services, say creating a new instance of some type.

  1. A new instance of the object would be created locally using the standard technique (e.g., new PSFolder("foo")).
  2. The object would be manipulated until it reached the desired state.
  3. The object would then be passed to the save method of this class.
  4. The proxy would look up the real processor and pass it the properties from the config file, which would include the name of the web service to use.
  5. The real processor would call toXml on the component and pass this element as the document when making the web service request. This request would be received by the web services handler at the server.
  6. The handler would re-create the original object, passing the supplied xml to the component's fromXml method.
  7. This object would then be passed to the local proxy processor's save method.
  8. The local proxy would look up the real processor and pass the config information. By default this processor will generate a new key and call toDbXml on the component and pass the generated fragment to the resource defined in the processor's config
  9. After this is successful, setPersisted is called on the component.
  10. Success is returned to the web service caller.
  11. The WS processor will call setPersisted on the remote object.
When the methods of a processor are called, a component type must be supplied (or it is obtained from the supplied component). In general, this should be the base name of the component (but for the relationship processor methods, it is an arbitrary name, usually based on the type of relationship being processed). This name is used to find the 'real' processor class name and a set of properties appropriate for this type of component. Most components will use the generic processor, which performs an internal request to a resource as described above.

Version:
1.0
Author:
Paul Howard

Constructor Detail

PSComponentProcessorProxy

public PSComponentProcessorProxy(String type,
                                 Object ctx)
                          throws PSCmsException
Creates a proxy for a specific type of processor. Simply delegates to the base class.

Parameters:
type - The type of processor for which this class is acting as a proxy. See version of the constructor for more details
ctx - A context object appropriate for the processor type, may be null if the processor does not require one.
Throws:
PSCmsException - If the xml document is not well-formed and conformant to its schema.
Method Detail

save

public PSSaveResults save(IPSDbComponent[] components)
                   throws PSCmsException
Description copied from interface: IPSComponentProcessor
Inserts or updates an existing object. The default processor will call the IPSDbComponent.toDbXml(org.w3c.dom.Document, Element, IPSKeyGenerator, PSKey) method of the supplied component and send that to the resource specified in the processor's config data. If a custom processor has been supplied, you would need to review the doc for that processor to determine what actions are taken, The net result though is that after this call completes, the object will be properly updated in the database.

After successful update, the setPersisted method of the component is called to re-synchronize with the database.

Specified by:
save in interface IPSComponentProcessor
Parameters:
components - The component(s) that need to be inserted or updated. The states of the supplied components will be checked first; any with DBSTATE_UNMODIFIED will be skipped. Never null. Any null entries will be skipped. The component type is obtained by calling getComponentType() on the elements. The type name is then used to find the processor properties in the config data. If an entry cannot be found, an exception is thrown.
Returns:
A set of components equivalent to the ones supplied (they may or may not be the exact ones supplied, depending on the processor) where each one will return true for isPersisted. You will get back the same component if it was unmodified when supplied. The returned components are not necessarily in the same order as when they were supplied. This object also contains statistics specifying how many components were saved or deleted.
Throws:
PSCmsException - If the processor for the supplied type is not found or cannot be instantiated, or any problems occur while getting the data.

load

public Element[] load(String componentType,
                      PSKey[] locators)
               throws PSCmsException
Description copied from interface: IPSComponentProcessor
Obtains 0 or more serialized versions of formerly persisted objects of the specified type that match the supplied locator(s). The returned xml can be passed directly to the fromXml method of the component whose type was supplied. Typically, this is the base name of the class (e.g., class com.percussion.cms.objectstore.PSSlot would use the type PSSlot).

Specified by:
load in interface IPSComponentProcessor
Parameters:
componentType - The base class name of the component being processed. Never empty or null. If the name is not found in the config, an exception is thrown.
locators - References to existing objects which you wish to re-serialize. All entries must be of the same type. If an entry cannot be found for a key, no Element will be returned. If the size of the returned array is less than the # of keys supplied, it is the responsibility of the caller to determine which keys were skipped because an object could not be found. If null, all objects of the requested type are returned. If any entry is null, an exception is thrown.
Returns:
An array with 0 or more xml fragments, each appropriate to populate an instance of the component whose name was supplied. An entry will be null if the supplied key does not reference an object of the specified type.
Throws:
PSCmsException - If the processor for the supplied type is not found or cannot be instantiated, or any problems occur while getting the data.

delete

public int delete(String componentType,
                  PSKey[] locators)
           throws PSCmsException
Description copied from interface: IPSComponentProcessor
Permanently deletes a specified set of components from the database. The caller is responsible for calling the IPSDbComponent.setPersisted() method on each component for which a key was supplied, if such a component exists.

Specified by:
delete in interface IPSComponentProcessor
Parameters:
componentType - The value returned by the getComponentType method of the component being processed. Never empty or null. If the name is not found in the config, an exception is thrown.
locators - References to existing objects which you wish to permanently remove from the system. If an entry cannot be found for a key, that key is skipped and processing continues normally. If null is found in the array, it is skipped and no error is reported.

You can determine which keys were skipped (if any) by calling the isAssigned method; it will return false for all successful deletes.

Returns:
The number of components actually deleted.
Throws:
PSCmsException - If the processor for the supplied type is not found or cannot be instantiated, or any problems occur while removing the data.

delete

public int delete(IPSDbComponent[] components)
           throws PSCmsException
Description copied from interface: IPSComponentProcessor
Convenience method that calls IPSComponentProcessor.delete(String,PSKey[]) for each group of components that have the same type.

If the deletion is successful, the setPersisted method of each IPSDbComponent is called.

Specified by:
delete in interface IPSComponentProcessor
Parameters:
components - The component(s) that need to be removed. The states of the supplied components will be checked first; any with unpersisted keys will be skipped. Never null and no entry may be null. The component type is obtained by calling getComponentType() on the entries. The type name is then used to find the processor properties in the config data. If an entry cannot be found, an exception is thrown.
Returns:
The number of components actually deleted.
Throws:
PSCmsException - If the processor for any of the types is not found or cannot be instantiated, or any problems occur while removing the data.
